Shiny Modules Can Return Anything

An epiphany about building flexible shiny modules by letting go of functional input-and-output thinking and embracing the return value.

Shiny modules, one epiphany at a time

Learning shiny modules is a path of epiphanies. On the one hand, they‚Äôre incredibly simple abstractions, but the outlines of the abstraction are a bit blurred and there‚Äôs just a hint of magic.

As a community, I don‚Äô think there‚Äôs a super clear consensus around when and how to teach Shiny modules. Some consider them advanced topics that most Shiny apps don‚Äôt need; others feel strongly that Shiny modules should be taught from the beginning and that everyone should be using Shiny modules. It‚Äôs similar to how R programmers feel about functions. They‚Äôre incredibly useful and more people could be using them, but there‚Äôs also a whole range of scripts and apps that are perfectly effective without them.

The end result is that many people learn and re-learn Shiny modules at different stages of the Shiny journey. The fun part is that each new thing you learn about modules are tiny epiphanies. Here are a few of my favorite üí° aha moments.

Epiphany: Shiny modules are tiny Shiny apps

Shiny modules exist to make parts of a Shiny app easier to understand, or easier to reuse in the same app, or easier to reuse in many Shiny apps. If you‚Äôre new to Shiny modules, then you might want to take a quick break and read these great articles: Emily Riederer‚Äôs Beginner‚Äôs guide to Shiny modules or Mastering Shiny: Shiny modules.

My first epiphany about modules was that you can think of a Shiny module as a mini Shiny app.

A Shiny module has the same components as a Shiny app: in the same way an app has a ui and a server, a Shiny module has a function that returns UI elements and a server function that contains the module‚Äôs server-side logic. You could pluck your module out of your big production app, give it the right kind of data or inputs, and have a small little Shiny app.

In fact, a great way to create a Shiny module is to start with a tiny Shiny app, get the behavior just right, and then wrap the tiny app up into a reusable module. You can see an example of this in the way Mastering Shiny introduces Shiny modules.

Toggle between app and module to see how the transformation is mostly a difference in boilerplate.

App

library(shiny)

ui <-
  fluidPage(
    selectInput("var", "Variable", names(mtcars)),
    numericInput("bins", "bins", 10, min = 1),
    plotOutput("hist")

)

server <-
  function(input, output, session) {
    data <- reactive(mtcars[[input$var]])
    output$hist <- renderPlot({
      hist(data(), breaks = input$bins, main = input$var)
    }, res = 96)

}

shinyApp(
  ui,
  server
)

Module

library(shiny)

histogram_ui <- function(id) {
  tagList(
    selectInput(NS(id, "var"), "Variable", choices = names(mtcars)),
    numericInput(NS(id, "bins"), "bins", value = 10, min = 1),
    plotOutput(NS(id, "hist"))
  )
}

histogram_server <- function(id) {
  moduleServer(id, function(input, output, session) {
    data <- reactive(mtcars[[input$var]])
    output$hist <- renderPlot({
      hist(data(), breaks = input$bins, main = input$var)
    }, res = 96)
  })
}

shinyApp(
  histogram_ui("hist1"),
  function(input, output, session) histogram_server("hist1")
)

Epiphany: Shiny modules are a convenient fiction

The hardest part of going from a tiny app to a Shiny module is finding all the places in your UI where you need to wrap an input ID in ns(). Colin Fay knows this.

In fact, ns() itself is another common source of epiphanies. When I learned Shiny modules, ns() seemed like a small piece of magic. I assumed whatever it did was complicated and required a deep and intimate understanding of the rest of Shiny‚Äôs magic. And when I learned that ns(id) uses no more magic than a simple paste0(namespace, "-", id) , I remember wondering if everything I had learned about Shiny modules was a lie. A convenient fiction, as Jon Harmon put it.

In Shiny, UI elements and server logic are completely disconnected. Neither part knows anything about the other. The only thing that connects them are the small strings we use as identifiers, the input or output IDs. When you call input$var in the server function, you‚Äôre hoping for the best that you‚Äôve included selectInput("var", ...) somewhere in your UI.

But input IDs aren‚Äôt special, they‚Äôre just strings that you have to type correctly and it‚Äôs up to you to make sure they‚Äôre unique. It‚Äôs the same for the IDs you give your shiny modules when you actually use them in your app. It‚Äôs up to you to make sure that histogram_ui("hist1") has a corresponding histogram_server("hist1").

The only thing that ns() does is prefix "var" with "hist1-" to create a unique ID "hist1-var". In the module‚Äôs server code, Shiny gives you a proxy input object with the "hist1-" prefix removed so you can call input$var. The fiction is that you have to call input$var from within moduleServer() or the elder callModule(). You don‚Äôt ‚Äì if you know the module‚Äôs prefix, you can call input$hist1-var anywhere in your apps‚Äô server code.

The namespacing mechanism behind modules is so simple that I really wish Shiny app authors didn‚Äôt have to worry about it at all. That you need to use ns() in your module‚Äôs UI function but don‚Äôt in your module‚Äôs server function is confusing and only adds to the feeling that some kind of magic is happening behind the scenes.

I‚Äôm fairly certain the need for ns() in the UI is a historical quirk in that Shiny it was easier to automatically adjust the IDs in the module‚Äôs input object than it would have been to automatically prefix IDs in the UI. In Shiny for Python, modules don‚Äôt require ns() anywhere.

Shiny modules are functions?

When Shiny modules are taught, they‚Äôre often presented in a functional context: a function returns the module‚Äôs UI, a function contains the server-side logic. This is a great starting place. But I often think of functions as units of code that take inputs and return outputs.

Shiny modules can be these kind of functions, but the reality is that what you are doing with these functions is decidedly not pure.

In fact, it can be particularly cumbersome to think of the module‚Äôs server function in the typical way, taking inputs, performing actions, and returning an output, especially when you‚Äôre accustomed to leaning into Shiny‚Äôs reactive programming model.

Recently, while working on a Shiny app, I had a realization that truly felt like an epiphany. It has since unlocked a new way of thinking about Shiny modules that feels like a balance between encapsulated code while still allowing Shiny‚Äôs powerful non-local reactivity. The epiphany: Shiny module functions can return anything.

Epiphany: Shiny modules can return anything

Imagine: an app about passenger volume between train stations. The user can pick from a set of stations. Not all stations connect with each other. Some stations are Express and others are Local, so there‚Äôs also a global control to switch between Express and Local stops.

Cutting floor

While I‚Äôve always appreciated carpenter-related metaphors for software development (and I do like calling myself a software engineer), I also have to admit that my shiny apps are rarely ever constructed from blue prints with precise measurements. My shiny apps aren‚Äôt built as much as they‚Äôre grown. I‚Äôm a terrible gardener. I can barely keep a house plant alive. My apps are grown like weeds, or trees that sprout in the cracks in concrete. My apps should have ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Mow, Let It Grow‚Äù signs in the source code.

The thing I‚Äôve always appreciated about Shiny is that it fully supports this method of development. Most Shiny apps start as a simple UI around a piece of code and a few questions.

Imagine a plot and a question: what if we broke this down by ____?

The question usually isn‚Äôt yours, but one you‚Äôre anticipating. You have the plot. And you know that as soon as they see it they‚Äôll wonder, what if we broke this down by ____?

You can do that quickly. There‚Äôs one place in your code where you change ‚ÄúX‚Äù to ‚ÄúY‚Äù or ‚ÄúZ‚Äù, hit Run Code and see the new plot. But there‚Äôs nothing slick about watching you type and hit enter. More importantly, you‚Äôre not letting them have the power of seeing the plot, asking the question, changing X to Y and seeing the new plot.

This is what Shiny does. With a few lines of code you have a dropdown and a plot. With selectInput() you create a dropdown with a few choices, they pick those choices, renderPlot() updates, new plot, win!
